title: Vintage Coffee Brands & Culture
description: From percolators to freeze-dried crystals, how well do you remember the coffee culture of decades past?

questions.question: Which coffee brand used the slogan 'Good to the last drop,' attributed to President Theodore Roosevelt?
questions.explanation: Maxwell House has used 'Good to the Last Drop' since 1917. Legend has it that President Theodore Roosevelt coined the phrase after drinking a cup at the Maxwell House hotel in Nashville.

questions.question: Which brand of instant coffee was the first widely available decaffeinated coffee in America?
questions.explanation: Sanka, introduced to America in 1923, was the first major decaffeinated coffee brand. Its name comes from the French 'sans caffeine' (without caffeine).

questions.question: What type of coffee maker was the standard in most American homes from the 1940s through the 1970s?
questions.explanation: The percolator was the standard American coffee maker for decades. The distinctive gurgling sound of a percolating pot was a familiar morning sound in homes across the country.

questions.question: Which Folgers coffee commercial featured a son coming home for the holidays and quietly brewing a pot of coffee to wake the family?
questions.explanation: The 'Peter Comes Home' Folgers commercial first aired in 1986 and became one of the most beloved holiday commercials in American television history.

questions.question: What was the name of the Folgers jingle that began 'The best part of waking up...'?
options: The Best Part of Waking Up Is Folgers in Your Cup
questions.explanation: 'The best part of waking up is Folgers in your cup' debuted in 1984 and became one of the most recognized jingles in advertising history.

questions.question: What instant coffee brand featured hidden camera taste tests in its 1970s and 1980s commercials?
questions.explanation: Folgers Crystals ran a famous series of commercials where they secretly replaced fine restaurant coffee with Folgers instant coffee and filmed diners' reactions.

questions.question: Which coffee brand featured a fictional character named Juan Valdez and his donkey?
options: Colombian Coffee (National Federation of Coffee Growers)
questions.explanation: Juan Valdez was created in 1958 by the National Federation of Coffee Growers of Colombia. The mustachioed farmer and his mule became icons of Colombian coffee quality.

questions.question: What Nestlé instant coffee brand ran a romantic soap-opera-style series of TV commercials in the 1980s?
questions.explanation: Taster's Choice ran a serialized series of romantic commercials featuring two neighbors who kept meeting over cups of coffee. The story played out over multiple episodes.

questions.question: What was the standard way coffee was typically served at a diner in the 1950s and 1960s?
options: In a heavy ceramic mug with free refills
questions.explanation: Diner coffee was served in thick, heavy ceramic mugs, and the waitress would come by with the coffee pot for free refills. This tradition continues at many diners today.

questions.question: What automatic drip coffee maker, introduced in 1972, eventually replaced the percolator in most American homes?
questions.explanation: Mr. Coffee, introduced in 1972 and famously endorsed by Joe DiMaggio, popularized the automatic drip coffee maker and eventually replaced the percolator as the standard home coffee maker.

questions.question: What small kitchen item was used to serve cream for coffee at the table in many mid-century homes?
questions.explanation: A small cream pitcher (or creamer) was part of every proper table setting. It was often matched with a sugar bowl as part of a set, sometimes in china or ceramic.

questions.question: What powdered non-dairy creamer was introduced in 1961 as an alternative to real cream?
questions.explanation: Nestlé's Coffee-mate was introduced in 1961 as the first non-dairy creamer. It didn't need refrigeration and became a pantry staple in offices and homes across America.

questions.question: Which San Francisco-based coffee brand featured an Arab man in traditional dress on its yellow can?
questions.explanation: Hills Bros. Coffee, founded in San Francisco in 1878, featured an Arab man sipping coffee on its distinctive can. The brand was a West Coast favorite for generations.

questions.question: What was 'Postum,' the popular coffee alternative that many families drank during wartime rationing?
questions.explanation: Postum was a caffeine-free grain beverage made from roasted wheat bran and molasses. Created in 1895, it became especially popular during WWII when coffee was rationed.

questions.question: What New York-based coffee brand's slogan was 'Heavenly coffee! Better coffee a millionaire's money can't buy'?
questions.explanation: Chock full o'Nuts, originally a chain of New York nut shops that converted to lunch counters, used this memorable slogan for decades. Page Morton Black sang the famous jingle.
